result.msg:
Exploring DataFrames

http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/scala/index.html#org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Showing the schema of a DataFrame
The first important thing to know when working with a new DataFrame, is its schema. In order to show it, you can use the printSchema method. This method will print the field names, types, and whether they are nullable or not.

result.msg:
Showing the schema of a DataFrame

The first important thing to know when working with a new DataFrame, is its schema. In order to show it, you can use the printSchema method. This method will print the field names, types, and whether they are nullable or not.

paragraphs.text:
val clickstreamDf = sqlContext.read.parquet("clickstream_df.parquet")
clickstreamDf.printSchema

result.msg:

 |-- curr_id: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- n: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- prev_title: string (nullable = true)
 |-- curr_title: string (nullable = true)
 |-- type: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Showing rows in a DataFrame: the "show" action
One of the most common operations you'll perform when you explore data is, of course, showing it. By default, *show* will print the first 20 rows of the DataFrame

result.msg:
Showing rows in a DataFrame: the “show” action

One of the most common operations you'll perform when you explore data is, of course, showing it. By default, show will print the first 20 rows of the DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Counting the number of rows
To count how many rows a DataFrame has, just run myDf.count

result.msg:
Counting the number of rows

To count how many rows a DataFrame has, just run myDf.count

paragraphs.text: clickstreamDf.count

result.msg: res10: Long = 199

paragraphs.text:
%md If you just want to count non-null values for one column, you can use the "count" function

<http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/scala/#org.apache.spark.sql.functions$>

result.msg:
If you just want to count non-null values for one column, you can use the “count” function

http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/scala/#org.apache.spark.sql.functions$

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.count
clickstreamDf.select(count('prev_id)).show

result.msg:

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Getting some basic information on columns
Sometimes, you'll want to quickly get some insights on a column. The describe method is intended for numeric columns, even though it will return some values for non-numeric columns. It is important that the "count" we get for the column here actually counts non-null rows, that's why it's not equal for all of the columns

result.msg:
Getting some basic information on columns

Sometimes, you'll want to quickly get some insights on a column. The describe method is intended for numeric columns, even though it will return some values for non-numeric columns. It is important that the “count” we get for the column here actually counts non-null rows, that's why it's not equal for all of the columns

paragraphs.text: clickstreamDf.describe("prev_id", "prev_title", "n").show

%md ### Sampling
Even though we won't need it for this training, it can be faster to work on a small subset of the data, if you just want to make some tests. You can use the "sample" method for that. It takes two parameters:
- withReplacement: true / false
- fraction: The percentage of the data that we want to take
- We can optionally add a seed, if we want to make sure we always get the same sample.

result.msg:
Sampling

Even though we won't need it for this training, it can be faster to work on a small subset of the data, if you just want to make some tests. You can use the “sample” method for that. It takes two parameters:

  • withReplacement: true / false
  • fraction: The percentage of the data that we want to take
  • We can optionally add a seed, if we want to make sure we always get the same sample.

paragraphs.text: %md If you want to get the same sample twice, you should use the seed parameter.

result.msg: If you want to get the same sample twice, you should use the seed parameter.

paragraphs.text:
%md ### What's going on under the hoods?
The "explain" command gives information about the different plans of the DataFrame, or to put it in another way, about the different stages that will happen when we run an action over the DataFrame. By default, it will show only the Physical Plan, but we can use explain(true) if we wanted to see all of the plans.

Let's compare the physical plans of the "clickstreamDf" another DataFrame that filters and selects some fields.

You can find a more detailed explanation on the plans and Catalyst optimizer here:

<https://databricks.com/blog/2015/04/13/deep-dive-into-spark-sqls-catalyst-optimizer.html>

result.msg:
What's going on under the hoods?

The “explain” command gives information about the different plans of the DataFrame, or to put it in another way, about the different stages that will happen when we run an action over the DataFrame. By default, it will show only the Physical Plan, but we can use explain(true) if we wanted to see all of the plans.

Let's compare the physical plans of the “clickstreamDf” another DataFrame that filters and selects some fields.

You can find a more detailed explanation on the plans and Catalyst optimizer here:

https://databricks.com/blog/2015/04/13/deep-dive-into-spark-sqls-catalyst-optimizer.html

paragraphs.text: clickstreamDf.explain

result.msg:
== Physical Plan ==
Scan ParquetRelation[prev_id#18,curr_id#19,n#20,prev_title#21,curr_title#22,type#23] InputPaths: file:/data/clickstream_df.parquet

paragraphs.text: %md The physical plan will get way more verbose quite quickly..

result.msg: The physical plan will get way more verbose quite quickly..

paragraphs.text:
clickstreamDf
  .filter("curr_id % 2 = 0")
  .select("type")
  .distinct
  .explain

result.msg:

Aggregate [type#23], [type#23]
+- Project [type#23]
   +- Filter ((curr_id#19 % 2) = 0)
      +- Relation[prev_id#18,curr_id#19,n#20,prev_title#21,curr_title#22,type#23] ParquetRelation
